introduction.p: Recall the five Laws of Exponents.

solution.p: Rearrange the factors to group together the numerical coefficients and the powers of each base. (2x^2y)(5x^4y^3) = (2)(5)x^2x^4yy^3 Multiply the coefficients together, and use the first law of exponents to find the products of the variable factors. (2)(5)x^2x^4yy^3 = 10x^6y^4 ~~~~~~~~ \blert{\text{Add exponents on each base.}}
Apply the fourth law of exponents and square each factor. (5a^3b)^2 = 5^2(a^3)^2b^2 = 25a^6b^2 ~~~~~~~~ \blert{\text{Apply the third law: multiply exponents.}}

introduction.p: Remember that a negative exponent indicates a reciprocal, so for example x^{-2} = \dfrac{1}{x^2} A negative exponent does not mean that the power is negative. So for example 4^{-2} = \dfrac{1}{16}; 4^{-2} does not mean -16.

li.p: To compute a negative power of a fraction, we compute the corresponding positive power of its reciprocal. Thus, \left(\dfrac{x}{4}\right)^{-3} = \left(\dfrac{4}{x}\right)^3 = \dfrac{64}{x^3}

introduction.p: If we move the decimal point to the left, we are making a number smaller, so we must multiply by a positive power of 10 to compensate. If we move the decimal point to the right, we must multiply by a negative power of 10.

statement.p:
Write each number in scientific notation.
62,000,000
0.000431

li.p: First, we position the decimal point so that there is just one nonzero digit to the left of the decimal. 62,000,000 = 6.2 \times To recover 62,000,000 from 6.2, we must move the decimal point seven places to the right. Therefore, we multiply 6.2 by 10^7. 62,000,000 = 6.2 \times 10^7

First, we position the decimal point so that there is just one nonzero digit to the left of the decimal. 0.000431 = 4.31 \times To recover 0.000431 from 4.31, we must move the decimal point seven places to the right. Therefore, we multiply 4.31 by 10^{-4}. 0.000431 = 4.31 \times 10^{-4}

statement.p:
Write each number in scientific notation.
The largest living animal is the blue whale, with an average weight of ~120,000,000~ grams.
The smallest animal is the fairy fly beetle, which weighs about ~0.000005~ grams.
